answer_html: Thus if \(\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3\) we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 2\) which is as claimed in the question.
answer_latex:
Thus if
$\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3$ we have that $\displaystyle \alpha = 2$
which is as claimed in the question.
hints_html: Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
hints_latex:
Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a
lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
hints_raw: Suppose a number has at least two distinct prime divisors. What is a lower bound on the number of divisors in this case?
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
The answer is true.

Suppose that n has at least two distinct prime divisors p and q. Then it has at least 4 positive divisors given by \(\displaystyle 1,p,q,pq\). Thus n must only have one prime divisor, so must be of the form \(\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}\). In this case, n has exactly \(\displaystyle \alpha +1\) positive divisors, namely, \(\displaystyle p^\beta\) for \(\displaystyle \beta = 0,1,2,\ldots,\alpha\). Thus if \(\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3\) we have that \(\displaystyle \alpha = 2\) which is as claimed in the question.
sols_latex:
The answer is \textbf{true}.

Suppose that \emph{n} has at least two distinct prime divisors \emph{p}
and \emph{q}. Then it has at least 4 positive divisors given by
$\displaystyle 1,p,q,pq$. Thus \emph{n} must only have one prime
divisor, so must be of the form $\displaystyle n = p^{\alpha}$. In this
case, \emph{n} has exactly $\displaystyle \alpha +1$ positive divisors,
namely, $\displaystyle p^\beta$ for
$\displaystyle \beta = 0,1,2,\ldots,\alpha$. Thus if
$\displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3$ we have that $\displaystyle \alpha = 2$
which is as claimed in the question.
sols_raw:
The answer is '''true'''. 

Suppose that ''n'' has at least two distinct prime divisors ''p'' and ''q''. Then it has at least 4 positive divisors given by <math> \displaystyle 1,p,q,pq</math>. Thus ''n'' must only have one prime divisor, so must be of the form <math> \displaystyle n = p^{\alpha} </math>. In this case, ''n'' has exactly <math> \displaystyle \alpha +1</math> positive divisors, namely, <math> \displaystyle p^\beta </math> for <math> \displaystyle \beta = 0,1,2,\ldots,\alpha </math>. Thus if <math> \displaystyle \alpha + 1 = 3</math> we have that <math> \displaystyle \alpha = 2</math> which is as claimed in the question.
statement_html:
State whether the following are true or false with full justification. Each question carries 4 marks.

If a positive integer has exactly 3 positive divisors, then it is necessarily of the form \(p^{2}\) where p is a prime.
statement_latex:
\textbf{State whether the following are true or false with full
justification. Each question carries 4 marks.}

If a positive integer has exactly 3 positive divisors, then it is
necessarily of the form $p^{2}$ where \emph{p} is a prime.
statement_raw:
'''State whether the following are true or false with full justification. Each question carries 4 marks.'''

If a positive integer has exactly 3 positive divisors, then it is necessarily of the form <math> p^{2} </math> where ''p'' is a prime.
